Scheme 1 Representation of the most possible chemical pathway for the synthesis of the heterogeneous Pd catalyst. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Cross coupling reaction in the synthesis of PPV and (PPV-(OC12)2) by using the supported Pd-SiNP catalyst. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 Plasma reactor system used for the pretreatment of SiNP. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Evolution in the XPS survey spectra of the diverse silica nanoparticles synthesis in accordance with Scheme 1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 High resolution XPS spectra for pristine silica particles HO-SiNP: a) Si2p and b) O1s. De-convoluted peaks and the fitted spectra are also inserted. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 High resolution XPS spectra for CS-SiNP: a) Si2p, b) O1s, c) S2p, and d) C1s. De-convoluted peaks and the fitted spectra are also inserted. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 High resolution XPS spectra for Lig-SiNP: a) N1s and b) C1s. De-convoluted peaks and the fitted spectra are also inserted; where Py is referred to the pyridine. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 High resolution XPS spectra for Pd-SiNP: a) Pd3d and b) N1s. De-convoluted peaks and the fitted spectra are also inserted. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 High resolution Pd3d XPS spectrum for PdNP-SiNP. De-convoluted peaks and the fitted spectrum are also inserted. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 TEM and HRTEM images of PdNP-SiNP deposited on Lacey carbon grid: a) bright field image of a set of NP, b) dark field image of a set of NP, c) bright field image of isolated NP, d) dark field image of isolated NP, e) HRTEM image, and f) SAED pattern. Graphical abstract The preparation of a recyclable palladium complex supported on coated silica nanoparticles (SiNP) and its effectiveness as a catalyst in the Heck reaction is described. Functionalized silica-based NP were synthesized in three steps. First, commercial SiNP were subjected to a CS2 cold plasma. Thus, a thin coating film was formed, along with the creation of a thiol functional surface. Subsequently, a thiol-ene reaction with 2-vinylpyridine induced by AIBN produced (Py)-CH2-CH2S covalently bonded to the SiNP, which after PdCl2(CH3CN)2, ligand exchange afforded the corresponding palladium complex catalyst (Pd-SiNP). Functionalized Pd-SiNP were characterized by SEM, ICP, and XPS spectroscopy. The SiNP were straightforwardly converted to an effective palladium catalyst applicable in a number of Heck cross-coupling reactions with iodobenzene (IBz) and a variety of vinyls. Indeed, such heterogeneous catalyst probed to be recyclable (up to 9 times). Nevertheless, leaching of metal was evidenced by TEM, HRTEM, XRD, and XPS. Furthermore, due to the outstanding results, we extended the use of the new heterogeneous catalyst to achieve the synthesis of a soluble phenylenevinylene type (PPV) copolymer from 1,4-bis(dodecyloxy)-2,5-diiodobenzene and p-divinylbenzene (DVB). Keywords plasma pretreatment polymerization silica nanoparticles supported Pd(II) complexes Heck reaction 1 Introduction Cross-coupling reactions by Pd-ligand catalysts of aryl halides with olefins have been broadly studied since the catalyst discovery by Heck [1], and Mizoroki et al. [2]. Thenceforth, a huge variety of new soluble Pd complexes and supported Pd catalysts for C-C coupling reactions is reported each year [3–6]. However, a significant drawback of the Pd complexes as homogeneous catalysts is associated to its recovery, or elimination of Pd residues in the crude products, which are generally difficult or impossible to attain. In this sense, heterogeneous catalysis has been an outstanding alternative to overcome this issue. Solid supported palladium catalysts have many advantages including ease of recovery, low overall cost and effort for the purification of final products. Additionally, the potential to reuse the supported Pd catalyst often makes it the more economically efficient choice. Palladium supported on solid materials such as carbon [7], amorphous [8], or ordered silicates [9,10], clay [11–13], and zeolites [14] are commonly employed in catalysis. Other methods to support Pd-Ligand catalysts include microencapsulation in core-shell block copolymers [15] or by immobilization on pre-functionalized surfaces bearing ligands that coordinate to Pd metal like phosphines [16,17] and pincer ligands [18,19]. Particularly, silica nanoparticles (SiNP) are attracting attention as support [20–22], because of their large surface area, low price, environmental friendship, stability in organic solvents, and the presence of silanol groups on their surface, which is suitable to further chemical modification. On the other hand, surface modification by plasma polymerization is a unique procedure used to enhance surface properties such as biocompatibility, hydrophilicity, etc. This type of modification involves the deposition of a cross-linked thin film on the exposed material, which can be e.g. synthetic [23] or natural polymers [24,25], and inorganic particles [26]. Here, we report the functionalization of SiNP by CS2 cold plasma to yield thiol groups on their surface, which then were reacted with 2-vinylpyridine through a thiol-ene reaction to afford a (2-pyridine)-CH2CH2S- prospective ligand, able to coordinate Pd(II) salts. The catalytic activity of the new Pd-SiNP complex was assessed trough the formation of carbon-carbon bonds under Heck’s reaction conditions between iodobenzene (IBz) and a variety of substituted vinyls either with electron-attractor or weak electron-donor groups. The electron attractor character of the vinyl substituent favors both, the E isomer regioselectivity and the high conversion, while cross-coupling of IBz with vinyls having a weak electron-attractor group gives rise to a mixture of products. In contrast, the Pd-SiNP resulted inactive in reactions carried out with bromobenzene. The use of new catalyst was extended to the polycondensation reaction of 1,4-bis(dodecyloxy)-2,5-diiodobenzene with p-divinylbenzene (DVB), affording a highly fluorescent copolymer of the phenylenevinylene (PPV) type in high yields. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Spherical nanoparticles of silica (HO-SiNP, Ø = 100 nm, surface area of ∼2-6 m²/g) were obtained from Fiber Optic Center Inc. New Bedford, MA, USA. The following chemical products were obtained from Aldrich and used without further purification: PdCl2(CH3CN)2, iodobenzene, styrene, butyl acrylate, acrylonitrile, acrylic acid, acrylamide, methyl methacrylate, propene, 2-vinylpyridine, carbon disulfide (CS2), dimethyl formamide (DMF), p-divinylbenzene (DVB) technical grade, 80 %, deuterated chloroform (CDCl3), 2,2’-azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN) previously crystalized from methanol twice. Palladium standard for ICP was obtained from Fluka Analytical. All of the solvents such as toluene, methanol, chloroform, were purchased from Aldrich, Baker and ASLO Reactivos. Triethylamine (Et3N) was distilled from KOH, tetrahydrofuran (THF) was distilled from sodium/benzophenone until a typical blue complex was developed. 2.2 Equipment The NMR spectra were obtained at room temperature using a 300 MHz Jeol Eclipse spectrometer or a 500 MHz Bruker Avance III. The chemical shifts in both 1H and 13C-NMR spectra were referenced to a residual no deuterated solvent, in this case CDCl3. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution electron transmission microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained from deposited materials by casting from CHCl3 dispersions on Lacey carbon grids in an FEI-TITAN-200-300 kV field emission gun microscope, which has a symmetrical condenser-objective lens type S-TWIN (with a spherical aberration Cs = 1.25 mm). X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique was realized on a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer with a scanning interval in the 2θ range of 10 to 50° with a scan speed of 0.02°/s, the radiation employed was copper Kα with a wavelength of 1.54056 Å, values of 25 Ma and 35 Kv were used for intensity and voltage, respectively. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken in a SM510 TOPCON microscope, or on a QUANTA 200 3D, operating at 30 KV from samples also casting deposited on carbon grids. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were performed in a PHI 5000 VersaProbe II X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. The X-ray source used was a monochromatic Al anode (1486.6 eV). The surveys were obtained with 117.5 eV pass energy, the analysis region was 1350 to 0 eV. A dual beam charge neutralization system (PHI´s patented) was used to compensate for charging during XPS data acquisition. All measurements were made in an ultra-high vacuum (UHV) chamber at a pressure around 3 × 10-8 mbar. Quantitative elemental composition (in atom %) was calculated integrating the peak areas of the high resolution spectra of each atom, after Shirley baseline subtraction and using Schofield sensitivity factors corrected for instrumentation transmission function. Peaks were de-convoluted with Gaussian multi fit option in Origin 7.5 Pro, considering the binding energy of the experimental peak maxima, its full width at half maximum (FWHM) and the total area of the peak after baseline subtraction as fitting parameters. UV-Vis and fluorescence spectra of PPV-(OC12)2 were acquired with an Agilent 8453 and a Perkin Elmer 55B spectrophotometers, respectively. The optical band gap, Eg, was found by drawing the tangent at OD = 0.1 of the normalized absorption spectrum. Emission spectra and fluorescence quantum yield φ were obtained on three solutions with OD at the excitation wavelength (λexc = 398 nm), between 0.02 and 0.1. Quinine sulfate (φ = 0.54 at λexc = 310 nm, 0.1 M H2SO4 solution) was used as standard [27]. Fluorescence lifetimes were obtained by TCSPC (time-correlated single photon counting) with a Tempro Horiba instrument with a 370 nm nanoLED and using a 0.01 % suspension of Ludox AS40 (Aldrich) in ultrapure water for the prompt signal. Calibration of the equipment was realized with a POPOP [1,4-bis(4-methyl-5-fenil-2-oxazolyl)benzene] methanol solution (optical density < 0.1) and lifetime of 0.93 ns [28]. Data fit was made using DAS6 software. 2.3 Palladium determination by ICP The Pd amount of the functionalized silica-ligand-Pd was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES), using a Thermo Scientific iCAP 7400 DUO analyzer. First, a calibration curve is made using a Pd commercial standard for ICP (1000 mg/L Pd in hydrochloric acid from Fluka). Then, 0.05 g of Pd-SiNP were digested in 1 mL of H2SO4 for 3 h and let them reach room temperature, follow by the addition of 1 mL of HNO3 and repose for 2 h. The solution was filtered through a paper No. 42. Then, the solution was gauged with distilled water until a final volume of 50 mL. The sample was injected to the instrument obtaining the result by duplicate. 2.4 Plasma pretreatment for CS-SiNP synthesis CS2 plasma modification of silica nanoparticles (HO-SiNP) was carried out in an Advanced Energy AFX400 radio frequency plasma generator at 50 W. The plasma generator system, depicted in Fig. 1 , consisted in a rotary glass reactor that assured that SiNP were in continuous movement during the plasma pretreatment. The system is comparable to the one described by Neira-Velázquez et al. [29] and Zendejo-Covarrubias et al.[30] To carry out the treatment, 78 mg of HO-SiNP were charged in the rotary glass plasma reactor and vacuum applied up to reach 8.5 × 10-6 Mbar. After 15 min of stabilization of the plasma system, carbon disulfide was introduced until the pressure reached 9.0 × 10-5 Mbar. Then, after 30 min of stabilization at this pressure, the plasma generator started applying the following reaction conditions: 100 W of input power for 30 min (NG 100 W-5 min) (30 kJ) and at 100 W (input power) for 60 min (NG 100 W-60 min) (360 kJ); 1 W = 1 J/s. After this treatment, the particles were removed from the plasma reactor, then water-HCl (pH = 5) was added to the plasma-treated SiNP, followed by chloroform workup to form the thiol groups [31]. The so functionalized SiNP (CS-SiNP) were vacuum dried for 12 h at room temperature. 2.5 Thiol-ene reaction for Lig-SiNP synthesis In a Schlenk tube under argon atmosphere and containing 0.5 mL (4.75 mmol) of 2-vinylpyridine, 78 mg (0.475 mmol) of recrystallized AIBN, and 78 mg of CS-SiNP were added 5 mL of dry toluene. The reactants were bubbled with argon for 35 min, and then heated in an oil bath to 80 °C for 3 h. After cooling, the nanoparticles were washed twice with toluene, then with methanol and isolated by centrifugation-decantation and vacuum dried for 12 h. 2.6 Pd complexation for Pd-SiNP synthesis In a Schlenk tube were placed 61 mg (0.23 mmol) of PdCl2(CH3CN)2 and 2 mL of CHCl3. Once the dissolution was completed, 103 mg of ligand functionalized Lig-SiNP were introduced and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Then, the Pd-SiNP catalyst was washed twice with CHCl3 and vacuum dried for 12 h. 2.7 General procedure for Heck coupling reactions The catalytic studies of Pd-SiNP in Heck reactions were conducted in a Schlenk tube equipped with a Teflon stopcock. Typically, a 25 mL Schlenk tube was charged with 10 mg of Pd-SiNP, 112 μL (1 mmol) of IBz (I-C6H5), 287 μL (2 mmol) of butyl acrylate (AcBu) (C7H12O2), 279 μL (2 mmol) of Et3N, and 1 mL of DMF. Next, the tube was connected to the vacuum line, “freeze-pump-thaw”, degassed for three cycles, and sealed under vacuum. Then, the tube was placed in an oil bath at 80 °C for 22 h, after heating for a few minutes the color of Pd-SiNP changed from brown to black and remained at this color until the end of reaction time. At this moment, the tube was taken off and let it reach room temperature. The tube was opened and a sample was taken for 1H-NMR analysis. A similar procedure was followed for the coupling reaction between IBz and the following vinyls: styrene, acrylonitrile, acrylic acid, acrylamide, and methyl methacrylate. In the case of the reaction between IBz and propene (C3H6), the addition of this gas was done as following; the propene tank and the Schlenk tube (previously charged with 10 mg of Pd-SiNP, 112 μL (1 mmol) of IBz, 279 μL (2 mmol) of Et3N, and 1 mL of DMF) were connected to the vacuum line and by means of a mercury manometer, the propene volume was measured, transferring it by vacuum to the tube. The tube was closed and removed from the vacuum line and introduced to the oil bath at 80 °C for 22 h. At the end of the reaction the tube was allowed to cool at room temperature and opened to perform the 1H-NMR analysis of the crude product. During the opening of Schlenk tube, the excess of propene was released. 2.7.1 Recycling catalyst procedure The Pd catalyst was fully recovered at each reaction just by filtering-washing with toluene and then used in a new experiment. Although it has been reported that ammonium salts stabilize Pd nanoparticles and promote successful Heck type cross-coupling reactions [12,32], in our work we did not study the effect of the ammonium salts generated during the reactions on the catalyst, but we focused mainly in the catalytic activity after filtration process. It worth to be mentioning, that toluene does not dissolve the ammonium salt, just the remaining cross-coupled products. 2.8 Synthesis of copoly(phenylenevinylene) In a Schlenk tube containing 94 mg (0.716 mmol) of DVB, 500 mg (0.716 mmol) of 1,4-bis(dodecyloxy)-2,5-diiodobenzene, and 10 mg of Pd-SiNP, were added 1 mL of dry and degassed DMF and 1.59 g (2.15 mmol) of Et3N via cannula. Afterward, the Schlenk tube was heated in an oil bath at 80 °C for 48 h under argon atmosphere. After cooling, the precipitated was filtered off and washed with THF. The solution was evaporated at the minimum of volume and precipitated twice in methanol. The precipitated was diluted in CHCl3, filtered, and kept in solution up to its further analyses. The precipitated retained in the filter was washed successively with methanol in order to eliminate the ammonium salt and recover the Pd-SiNP catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst synthesis The synthesis pathway for the heterogeneous catalyst with some of the most possible structures is depicted in Scheme 1 . Commercial HO-SiNP were subjected to a CS2 plasma created by an electrical glow discharge at different times. We found that the best treatment time for functionalization was 90 min. According to the SN2 reaction mechanism, the Si-O-H is substituted in the + C(S-)=S to give rise to a dithionic acid and/or to dithiol groups as depicted in Scheme 1 for CS-SiNP. The energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) obtained from SEM, Fig. 2 S, allowed us in to confirm the presence of sulfur on the nanoparticle; the type of functional sulfur groups formed and their percentage were assessed by XPS (vide infra). In the EDX spectra, the abundance of sulfur on the SiNP seems not to be in large amount because of the strong signals of Si and O atoms caused by their relative larger abundance. The -SH functionalized CS-SiNP underwent the thiol-ene “Click” reaction with 2-vinylpyridine in presence of AIBN in toluene and heating at 80 °C, the reaction evolution was followed by determining the 2-vinylpyridine consumption by TLC, at ca. 3 h. The SEM-EDX spectrum, Fig. 3 S, shows the presence of O, Si, C, and it also confirmed the S and N elements. The produced Lig-SiNP were subjected to ligand exchange with PdCl2(CH3CN)2 in chloroform at room temperature. The SEM-EDX spectrum, Fig. 4 S, confirms the presence of Pd and Cl atoms. The so formed Pd-SiNP were kept in a glass vial and store at room temperature. 3.2 X-ray photoelectron spectra To obtain information on the structural features of the Pd-SiNP catalyst, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies have been performed on the products of the different synthesis steps and on the catalyst recovered after 9 catalytic cycles PdNP-SiNP. Fig. 2 shows the XPS survey spectra for the series: from the pristine silica (bottom) to the recycled catalyst (top), and Table 1 resumes all the determined element compositions. The pristine silica particles HO-SiNP present the typical Si signals: Si2p at 103 eV and Si2s at 156 eV together with the corresponding O peaks (O1s at 535 eV, O2s at 27 eV and Auger OKL1 and OKL2 at 980 and 1003 eV, respectively). The relative atom percentage is 1:1.9 quite in agreement with SiO2 stoichiometry. A very weak C1s signal at 285 eV is also found, likely due to residuals from synthetic procedures [33] or ambient contaminants. After CS2 plasma pretreatment, CS-SiNP, additionally to the Si and O previous signals, the C1s peak at 285 eV gets intensity and new signals appear relative to S: S2s at 164 eV and S2p at 227 eV, with an overall atomic percentage similar to that of Si and C. After reaction with 2-vinylpyridine, Lig-SiNP, the S percentage decreases, which indicates that the reaction conditions and the presence of the AIBN radical eliminates some sulfur atoms. This explains why the N1s signal that appears at 400 eV due to pyridine functionalization is a very weak signal giving only 1.83 atomic % for this element. Despite that, in the step of Pd complexation, Pd-SiNP, the percentage of S and N is preserved. The presence of the typical Pd3d signals at 337 eV (3d5) and 342 (3d3) confirms the final expected functionalization, however these peaks are weak and their corresponding atomic percentage is very low (0.11 %) as a consequence of the yet low percentage of the two elements (S and N) required for the Pd complexation. In order to get information on the possible chemical functionalization of silica particles, after each reaction, high resolution (HR) spectra of the representative elements were obtained. In the pristine silica, Fig. 3, the Si2p signal is a symmetric peak, which is de-convoluted in two Gaussian peaks at 103.96 eV and 104.90 eV and are assigned to Si-OH and Si=O bonds of silica, respectively [34]. Correspondingly, the O1s HR spectrum presents two fitted peaks, at 533.35 eV due to Si=O and at 534.28 eV ascribed to Si-OH. After CS2 plasma treatment, Fig. 4 for CS-SiNP, the high Si2p resolution spectrum still presents two de-convoluted peaks: at 103.95 eV and at 105.18 eV, which assignment is discussed later. HR O1s spectrum is well fitted with four Gaussian peaks: at 531.68 eV, 533.03 eV, 533.85 eV and 535.03 eV. Considering the reactions pathway of Scheme 1 and the previous assignments to pristine silica, the peak at 531.68 eV is ascribed to Si=O and that at 533.85 eV to Si-OH. The additional two peaks can be assigned to Si-O-C=S (535.03 eV) and to Si-O-C-S (533.03 eV) groups. Consequently, the peak at 103.95 eV for Si2p is assigned to Si-OR, while the signal at 105.18 eV is defined as Si=O, where R can be H or C=S/C-SH. As the functionalization is directly achieved on the oxygen, it is reasonable to consider that the Si2p electrons of the Si-O bonds cannot be “distinguished”, therefore just one peak is found at this energy binding. A support to the possible functionalization depicted in Scheme 1 comes from the HR spectra of S2p and C1s. Both spectra can be de-convoluted and two Gaussian peaks are displayed: 163.68/164.90 eV for S2p and 285.21/286.24 eV for C1s. Due to the high electronegativity of the double bond, and to the bonds expected on the basis of the reaction, for S2p, the peak at 164.90 eV is assigned to C=S, while that at 163.68 eV to C-SH. Correspondingly, in the C1s spectrum, the peak at 285.21 eV is ascribed to the C-SH bond and the 286.24 eV to C=S. After the thiol-ene Click reaction between –SH and 2-vinylpyridine to form Lig-SiNP, the SH groups are converted into -S-CH2. However, the change in the electronegativity among these two groups is not important, so that the HR S2p spectrum of Lig-SiNP presents two de-convoluted peaks as was observed in CS-SiNP. The Si2p and O1s HR spectra are also de-convoluted with two (Si2p) and four (O1s) peaks as in CS-SiNP, Fig. 5 S. Significant evidences of the thiol-ene functionalization is the presence of the N1s peak (Py) at 399.02 eV [35] and the additional de-convoluted peaks at 284.08 eV (C-C from the aliphatic chains) and at 287.54 eV (from aromatic carbons) that are found in the HR C1s spectrum in Fig. 5. The Pd complexation to form Pd-SiNP is supported by the appearance of the new Pd3d signals, Fig. 6 . Despite the low intensity, HR Pd3d spectrum, is fitted with two spin-orbit components at 336.84 and 342.18 eV, which are ascribed to Pd(II). The N1s HR spectrum reveals also the functionalization by fitting with two Gaussian de-convoluted peaks: at 399.06 eV (Py) and a new signal at 401.26 eV that can be ascribed to the complexation of some of Py nitrogens with Pd forming the “heterocycles”. This complexation also changes the O1s, C1s, and S2p HR spectra, Fig. 6S, as the previous signals ascribed to the C-S/C=S bond give rise to one band assigned (in the Figures legends) as “cycles”. It is important to notice that, after recovering the Pd catalysts PdNP-SiNP at the end of the Heck reaction, the survey spectrum; Fig. 2 still presents the same characteristic peaks as Pd-SiNP. Analyzing the HR spectra of the Pd, Fig. 7 , it can be observed that the spectrum can be de-convoluted with two pairs of spin-orbit components: 335.65/340.91 eV and 336.96/342.22 eV. The latter ones are at the same energy as found for Pd-SiNp and due to the complexed Pd, while the new signals, due to the low energy binding, are rather ascribed to Pd nanoparticles [36] that usually are formed during the coupling reaction [37], and as was supported by TEM-HRTEM (vide infra) and XRD analyses. 3.3 TEM, HRTEM, and XRD analyses of PdNP-SiNP Leaching of palladium after using the catalyst in the Heck reactions was evidenced by TEM and HRTEM, Fig. 8 . According to the TEM micrographs, recycled PdNP-SiNP catalyst exhibited the formation of Pd(0) nanoparticles aggregates on the surface. Likewise, the dark field TEM images show bright regions corresponding to Pd-NP. HRTEM analysis corroborated the presence of irregular crystal shapes with lattice planes with no preferential orientation. Furthermore, growth of metallic nanoparticles was confirmed by indexed selected area of the electron diffraction pattern (SAED), which showed clear lattice fringes with bright circular rings corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (311), and (331) planes of Pd metal with face centered cubic (fcc) structure (JCPDS-ICDD file no. 87-0638). In addition, XRD measurements of PdNP-SiNP (Fig. 7S) confirmed the presence of the crystalline phase corresponding to metallic Pd with two prominent Bragg reflections at 2θ = 40.1 and 46.6° that correspond to the 111 and 200 planes, respectively of the fcc crystal structure [38] along with the presence of an amorphous peak at 2θ = 23.3° attributed to the SiO2 particles [39]. 3.4 ICP analysis of Pd-SiNP The amount of Pd deposited on the surface of SiNP was determined by an inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyzer. The ICP analysis showed 3.274 % weight (32736.98 ppm) or 3.07 × 10-6 mol Pd in 10 mg of Pd-SiNP. 3.5 Catalytic activity of Pd-SiNP in the Heck reaction The catalytic activity of Pd-SiNP in the Heck reaction was evaluated under conditions generally applied in literature. In this work we used iodobenzene (IBz) with a variety of vinyls in DMF as solvent and Et3N as base, Table 2 . It is worth to mention that yieldings of the cross-coupling reactions by using bromobenzene were almost negligible or nulls, converting to this catalyst selective to iodobenzene. The reactions were followed by 1H NMR by determining in particular the consumption of the double bonds of the vinyls, and quantifying the E or Z isomer formation. As shown in Table 2, the catalytic activity was high, since the IBz consumption was completed in most cases. The electron attractor character of the vinyl substituent R1 1, 3-5, favors both, the regioselectivity; E isomer 1, 4, 5 and their high conversion. The trans isomerism is usually observed in the syn-insertion/syn-elimination step of the reaction mechanism for mono-substituted olefins [40]. In contrast, the electron donor character of benzene in styrene 2 and propylene 6 induces that the cross-coupling reaction with IBz can also be carried out with the more substituted carbon of the vinyl, forming e.g. isomer C: 1,1-diphenylethylene in 7 % and 1-propen-2-benzene in 31 %, respectively. In relation to MMA (Entry 7), which is di-substituted, the reaction forms both E-methyl-3-phenyl-2-methylpropenoate isomer (A), and methyl-2-benzylpropenoate isomer (B). The formation of these two isomers takes place because there is a dual pathway for the formation of the double bond in the β-hydride elimination step of the catalytic cycle. Compound Z-methyl-2-benzyl-3-phenylpropenoate corresponding to product (C), is obtained from the subsequent coupling of isomer (B) with IBz, as reported by Petrovic et al. [41], however in our conditions this product was not observed. The coupling constants, multiplicity, and chemical displacements were analyzed and compared with similar compounds reported in the literature. Table 3 summarizes the chemical shifts of the most characteristic groups of the obtained products. It is worth mentioning that at the very beginning of the first catalytic cross-coupling reaction, Pd-SiNP turned from light brownish-orange to black color, in literature the appearance of black-Pd has been attributed to different coordination complexes i.e. Pd(II), Pd(0), and Pd nanoparticles supported on the substrates [42]. In our case, this suspended black powder was filtered and washed with dry toluene to further test its catalytic activity. The black-Pd remained active to the coupling for up to 9 cycles (in the case of BuAc) with no activity loss, Table 4 . The re-use of the catalyst in the case of styrene shows the gradual decrease of the activity until its practically deactivation after the 7th cycle. The recycling of Pd-SiNP works better with butyl acrylate than styrene probably because Pd metal center remain complexed with the St aromatic ring, giving rise to the system leaching, for instance in the literature it has been reported the successful recycling of Pd-based catalyst in the Heck cross-coupling reaction of 4-bromoacetophenone with styrene for up to 5 cycles with yields of ca. 99 % [43], in contrast in the cross-coupling reaction of bromobenzene and styrene a rather abrupt fall activity in the first cycles was observed [44,45]. For comparison purposes Table 5 describes the catalytic activity for the Heck reaction using different supported PdNPs catalysts. In all cases, C-C coupling product was achieved in high yields and in most cases the catalyst was recycled. Particularly, the Pd/NH2SiO2 system turns to be highly active, with only 0.05 mol % of Pd content and in a short reaction period. In our catalytic system, Pd-SiNP resulted in a very similar activity and selectivity to those shown in Table 5. 3.6 Catalytic activity of Pd-SiNP in the Heck polycondensation reaction The activity of Pd-SiNP was tested in the synthesis of the conjugated poly(p-phenylenevinylidene) (PPV) and poly((2,5-dodecanoxy)-1,4-phenylenevinylene) (PPV-(OC12)2) by cross-coupling of the corresponding monomers as indicated in Scheme 2 , with yields of 50 and 74 %. The PPV is insoluble, making difficult either its characterization or its separation from catalyst residue. In contrast, the analogous substituted with lateral side chains (PPV-(OC12)2) is soluble in most organic solvents, allowing its spectroscopic and optical characterization. Fig. 9 shows the 1H-NMR spectrum of (PPV-(OC12)2), where it is observed that the aromatic protons overlap with those vinylic in the range 7.0 to 7.7 ppm. However, in the 13C-NMR spectrum and in the C-H correlation, HSQC (Fig. 8S), the aromatic and vinylic carbons differ very well in their chemical shifts. It is also observed that the experimental integration relationship between the protons (aromatic plus vinylic) with respect to the alpha methylenes to the dodecanoxy chains is close to 10/4 ratio, which is in agreement with the expected theoretical value with the repeat unit of the synthesized copolymer. The IR/KBr spectrum of (PPV-(OC12)2) shows two intense absorptions bands at 2924 and 2853 cm-1 characteristic of the aliphatic C-H stretching (Fig. 9S). Approximately, at 3080 cm-1 a weak vibrational signal assigned to the CH stretching of the vinyls in trans geometry is observed, this agrees by the presence of a signal of medium intensity at 965 cm-1 assigned to the flexion out of the plane of the CH trans vinyl [49]. The stretching band C=C that should be observed in the range of 1680-1600 cm-1 with medium intensity is observed with a displacement to lower wave numbers 1594 cm-1 as a weak signal. The same happened with the aromatic C-H stretching, which do not appear in the range of 3150-3050 cm-1 but are rather overlapped with the C-H stretching of the aliphatic part due to the extended conjugation of the polymer [49]. The optical spectra (Fig. 10 ) for (PPV-(OC12)2) were acquired in spectroscopic grade chloroform. The UV-Vis spectrum (black squares) shows the main peak ascribed to the π→π* electronic transition (HOMO→LUMO) at 408 nm with a molar absorptivity coefficient (ε) of 7.25 × 104 M-1 cm-1, (calculated on the basis of the molecular weight of the repetitive unit). Another band at 332 nm can be observed and likely due to HOMO-1→LUMO electronic transition as found for other alcoxy substituted arylenevinylidenes [50,51]. Eg is equal to 2.51 eV indicating the semiconducting character of the polymer. The fluorescence spectrum (red circles) presents a main peak at 480 nm, with fluorescence quantum yield of 40 % and a mono-exponential decay (Fig. 10S) from which a fluorescence lifetime of 1.32 ns is found. The corresponding excitation spectrum (green triangles) matches well the absorption one, revealing that there is only one emitting species. In general, the optical properties are blue shifted with those previously reported for alcoxy PPV [52] polymers and closer to trimers, however the present results are aimed to demonstrate the possibility to use the novel Pd supported catalysts in conjugated systems synthesis, and further optimization of the optical properties of the products is in progress. 4 Conclusions A novel method for the synthesis in three steps of a free phosphine ligand Pd(II) complex bonded to silica nanoparticles was developed and consisted on: functionalization of SiNP by CS2 plasma pretreatment to form thiols, which subsequently were subjected to thiol-ene reaction with 2-vinylpyridine to generate a bi-dentate ligand to coordinate Pd(II) metal center. Functionalized silica nanoparticles with palladium (Pd-SiNP) were characterized by ICP, SEM, and XPS techniques. High activity of the catalyst in the Heck reaction was demonstrated using iodobenzene as the aryl halide and a variety of vinyls bearing polar groups such as acids and amides or coordinating groups such as CN group of acrylonitrile. The formation of palladium (0) nanoparticles after Heck reactions was evidenced by TEM, HRTEM, XRD, and XPS spectroscopy. The application of the heterogeneous catalyst was extended to the synthesis of a soluble PPV from 1,4-bis(dodecyloxy)-2,5-diiodobenzene and DVB in high yields. It is also noteworthy that successful recycling of Pd-SiNP was achieved up to 9 times (in the case of BuAc). coredata.dc:description: The preparation of a recyclable palladium complex supported on coated silica nanoparticles (SiNP) and its effectiveness as a catalyst in the Heck reaction is described. Functionalized silica-based NP were synthesized in three steps. First, commercial SiNP were subjected to a CS2 cold plasma. Thus, a thin coating film was formed, along with the creation of a thiol functional surface. Subsequently, a thiol-ene reaction with 2-vinylpyridine induced by AIBN produced (Py)-CH2-CH2S covalently bonded to the SiNP, which after PdCl2(CH3CN)2, ligand exchange afforded the corresponding palladium complex catalyst (Pd-SiNP). Functionalized Pd-SiNP were characterized by SEM, ICP, and XPS spectroscopy. The SiNP were straightforwardly converted to an effective palladium catalyst applicable in a number of Heck cross-coupling reactions with iodobenzene (IBz) and a variety of vinyls. Indeed, such heterogeneous catalyst probed to be recyclable (up to 9 times). Nevertheless, leaching of metal was evidenced by TEM, HRTEM, XRD, and XPS. Furthermore, due to the outstanding results, we extended the use of the new heterogeneous catalyst to achieve the synthesis of a soluble phenylenevinylene type (PPV) copolymer from 1,4-bis(dodecyloxy)-2,5-diiodobenzene and p-divinylbenzene (DVB).
coredata.dc:title: Facile preparation of palladium catalyst supported on silica nanoparticles through CS2 plasma pretreatment: Application to the Heck reaction for vinyl monomers and π-conjugated polymer synthesis
